ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I took this course as a special project with Ann and did not participate in the full classroom sessions because of a timing conflict with another course. Working with Ann was great and I learned a lot from the two projects I took on to fulfill the requirements of the course.
I think a few more field trips into the field to try and identify some other health issues would be great. We did see the major ones though.

This course is necessary because pests and pathogens and climate will affect every forest in the world!It is necessary to know what is healthy and what is causing a lack of health. However, this course did not really spend time teaching specifics about different pests/pathogens... which I know would be difficult to do since there are so many and they differ by region, let alone country. To get past this, it was great to have individual presentations where the students could pick a topic that interested them specifically so that s/he could learn more about their area of focus!

This is a seminar course and you can expect to learn as much as you put in effort. I learned a lot about different forest health concepts, such as what is a "healthy" forest, particularly with respect to insects.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Student presentations, field trips to Guilford and URI.
Broad overview of various forest health issues.
Learning to identify pathogen and insect damage, and know how it spreads and what if anything can be done.

The best aspects were getting to the case study in Wisconsin to get a feel for how practitioners are actively dealing with forest health issues. I also liked getting to choose my own topic for the other two presentations, and getting to hear about many different areas/health concerns since my peers got to choose topics that interested them but that I would not have spent time learning on my own!
The case studies.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I'd have liked a recap of some of the most important elements of forest health by region

Course did not really become a discussion. One student would present material and peer students would not pay very close attention to what was being shared. As a result, I did not learn as much as I should have. I was not pushed hard enough in this course. Instructor should demand more from students.
Maybe a little bit more on a healthy forest v unhealthy forest from a standpoint of stand dynamics and regeneration and age classes. Also deer herbivory would play into this as well.

I would have preferred this course be more of an entomology course focused on identifying pests; maybe pathogens, too. I feel like I understand that there are pests, but I don't know anything deeper than that. The wide variety of topics made the course too broad, general, and conceptual. There could have been more case studies about individual pests and pathogens.
The syllabus, when updated, needs to be more clearly communicated.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was a little too skewed toward student presentations without enough synthesis from the profsesor.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Forest health is an important component of the MF curriculum.
An important course for any MF -- all MFs should be aware of major forest health issues.
Essential course for a forester. Connects to all other classes well.
Knowing about forest health is crucial for everyone that will be working in a location with forests!
You must evaluate the use of the word "healthy" in any ecosystem- this course will help you determine what definition is appropriate and how to analyze its state.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Forest health is important to learn about, and it added to my biology bucket.
Seemed important for MFs to be aware of forest health issues they may confront in their careers.
Essential Course.

Few courses have an explicit 'Urban' element and this one does! I was able to cater my presentations towards this area of focus so that I learned more about a setting so few forestry courses spend time discussing.
Interest.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I wish I came out with a list of issues, diseases, and pests that I could reference again, but I feel that I got exposure to a broad range of issues.
To some extent. I could have worked harder, but the bar was set low and expectations of students were not particularly high, so I focused more of my time and energy on more demanding courses.
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: 2 heads are better than 1.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep a running list of the issues, diseases, and pests.

This is a relatively easy class with limited work load (a few presentations, no paper and no exam). You get what you put into it, though I don't sense many students put a lot of energy or effort into the course.
Read the papers and do your research! You will be giving several presentations.
